Nice told with Alyx  HALF-LIFE 2 EPISODE 2 starts immediately where Half-Life 2 Episode 1 ended. Gordon Freeman and Alyx Vance must continue their fight, alongside the resistance, against the evil Combine. After the ever so slightly below par Episode 1, Episode 2 is a real return to form. Everything that was so good about HL2 is developed here and made even better. The narrative arc is strong, the dialogue well-written and witty, the voice acting accomplished and convincing, the environments spectacular and varied, and the mix between puzzle solving and combat just right. We meet several new enemies and some of the combat is pretty challenging, especially the final battle which is big on scale and mayhem and requires real strategy to complete. It’s a tough finale but well worth the effort. There’s so much to enjoy in the whole Half-Life series I can’t recommend these games enough.  5/5

I am just going to say this right now. I really loved this game. This is going to be a long review as well. Just sayin'.  Now, I do have reasons to say so. I personally disliked Half-Life 2, and Half-Life 2 Episode 1. Still buy them, because to get the full experience of Episode 2 you need to know not only the story, but how much the game improved.  Now, the entire Half-Life 1 (classic?) series was great, while sometimes buggy. What can I say? Golden Source is golden. The gameplay was smooth, the weapons were nice and powerfull-ish, and you played as a variety of characters.  (STILL BUY THIS GAME! SKIP IF YOU DON'T LIKE CRITICISM) Here is where Half-Lfe 2 comes in. Gordon Freeman in a City 17 train, waiting with the rest of the ctizens. Commence with an overly long section without even a crowbar, picking up and throwing spare junk. A little while after, you spend way too long speeding around in an airboat. Then the Gravity Gun, to pick up and throw even more spare junk, but at high speeds. A dunebuggy with suspension level ten thousand, not to mention two types of portable infinite ammo. Last but not least, the 1500 Megawatt Black Mesa Heavy Duty Super-Colliding Super Gravity Gun. One last way to run around with over 9000 HEV and the one weapon to rule them all. The NPCs in the game? 'Oh, Gordon Freeman. We worship you, even though you basically caused this whole mess and only saved yourself.' Barney Calhoun, the dropout hero of Blue Shift? 'Headhumper. Headhumper. Hey, I finally took one down!'  All of these were fun, but too drawn-out. No offense to Valve, but the majority of gamers can learn how to use a gimmick in much less time than otherwise thought. Overall, Half-Life 2 had long expanses of nothing, but in reality some of the best gameplay experiences I've ever had.  (SERIOUSLY, STILL BUY THIS GAME! YOU, THE READER, HAVE THE POWER TO SKIP AT ANY TIME!) Half-Lide 2 Episode 1. Where do I begin? Morg- Gordon Freeman wakes up, and for some reason goes right back into the Citadel. Here he aquires the Conveniently Temporary Over-Powered Blue Zero-Point Energy Manipulator. I didn't think highly of this game from up front, remembering the whimper in which Half-Life 2 ended. From here on, The gameplay is mostly indoors with airducts, similar to Half-Life 1. But, the story was meh. To add, Alyx's AI walked right up to every enemy, and died too often. The fights were really intense, though. All being said, the game kind of ended after about three hours and one strider.  Overall verdict: intense, even difficult action, but compressed into too little time, squeezing out story.  vvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvv Half-Life 2 Episode 2. This game is EXCELLENT. If I can say this to the entirety of Steam after knocking the rest of Half-Life 2, I must mean something. Gordon now wakes up inside of the train that crashed. As the train slowly topples over, the obstacle course that you need to climb down changes. I also happen to love changing terrain, so good first impression. Now I begin to notice things. The flashlight that wore out in about ten seconds in the other games was replaced with one much more similar to Half-Life 1. Also on an individual battery, allowing you to dash for more than a few seconds. I gaze deeply into my teammate's eyes, she awkwardly turns away to avoid eye contact. Very human of her. The car is come-and-go. You can struggle through most areas either with or without the car. It lasted just as long as it was needed. and no longer. As for action, there was never a point without it. All was unique, as well. Half-Life 2 got stale, while Episode 1 was overwhelming. Episode 2 managed to get just the right mix of the two, combining into THE perfect balance. Rochelle- I mean, Alyx's AI was realistic, even to the level of the player. Then there's the Gnome. My good friend the Garden Gnome. As a display of how much Valve in the greatest compaby on this side of the universe, you get an achievement for carrying this guy through almost the whole game. While a pain as some points, I kind of grew to like the guy. The ALyx Vance mauled by a Hunter? 'Don't look, Gnome. Shield thou purest of eyes.' It's a showcase of how great the gameplay is. You literally could have taken ANY item throughout the entire game. Now, back on topic. The Characters were recovered to what they should have been. Barney as a security guard. Refugees as refugees. The vortigaunts actually using their green electricity bolts. The characters were essential to the rich storyline. The storyline alone could have made a movie, as it was what made me start rooting for Half-Life 3. Basically, every problem that I have found in any other Half-Life game was remedied in this one fantastic sequel. ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^   Seriously, just buy the game.  Now.  Sell your house if you really have to.

WHAT THE HECK WAS THAT ENDING???  Episode 2 continues on where Episode 1 left off. Gordon and Alyx have already escaped from City 17 and have to get to White Forest - a resistance base. Throughout their journey they are constantly chased by the Combine.  While in Episode 1 the setting was mostly urban, in Episode 2 you traverse through the countryside and the area around it. When you have progressed enough through the game you will find an old muscle car that you will use to get to White Forest, func_vehicle returns in Episode 2, not seen in Episode 1. Not that much puzzles are tied to the passage of the car being blocked, though they still are present.  New enemies added include the notorious Hunters. They usually travel in packs and are tough opponents. Alyx is the first to have an experince with a Hunter and it seems that they are too strong, but they can be defeated relatively easy, depending on what you shoot them with. You will also face a lot of striders and obtain a new device used to destroy them - a Magnusson Device.  Episode 2 is made with the same engine as HL2 and Episode 1 so the graphics are the same.  In the end, if you have played the other games, but not this one, then you should buy it.

Half-Life 2: Episode 2 is an excellent continuation of the series, and introduces several fun new enemies and challenges, along with the unforgettable muscle car. I found it to be the most intense and difficult game of the Half-Life 2 anthology, especially in the finale (even on Easy). Episode 2 thrusts you back into the H.E.V. Suit of Gordon Freeman once more, but in a completely new forested environment. As the game progressed, I found it even more emotional than all the precursors, as well as giving a strong sense of buildup to a climax (HL3, anyone?). However, this Episode is not all glitter and sparkles. I did find the first hour or so of gameplay to be a bit redundant, but after that, it sucked me right back in. Anyway, Episode 2 is still a worthy addition to the franchise and a must-play for anyone remotely interested in the series, and still a great experience for anyone else. Totally worth buying.

Stories are not meant to be meaningless 'hero saves the day' / 'Hero's journey' clones. Stories are snippits from life that have both good AND bad endings. Stories tell of what happened, not a useless formula of success. Stories force us to deal with loss--the minor, the profound, and the unavoidable. Easily my favorite of the two Half-Life episodes (though I still recommend anyone to play the first one in order to understand what's going on, obviously). I was a bit skeptical, and honestly a little tired of the formula of the Half-Life games and had a lurking suspicion that Episode Two would just follow a stream of monotony. But of all four Half-Life installments, I'd definitely say this one had the biggest emotional impact on me. The moment that Episode Two hooked me, was when I had to avoid getting killed by The Guadrian down in the caves. I never felt such a strange experience of fear and adrenaline, as I'd hear The Guardian thumping down the halls and I'd race for the nearest hole to hide in.  Episode Two is filled with plenty more memorable moments beyond this. Without spoiling the story, there were plenty of moments I'd feel very unique emotions (stress, unease, sadness, relief) during some of the most enjoyable moments in the Half-Life series. The only problem I have with the game are it's plot conveniences. Like when you happen to find the vortigaunts after trekking through the maze of caves. Or how the vortigaunts are able to undo something that seemed to me already done (again, without spoiling anything). And of course, the semi-cliff-hanger ending. Episode One ended on more of a final note. Like the loose ends were tied, even though there was still something else to do. Episode Two leaves a wide open gap in story that I know plenty of gamers want to know (which now I completely understand, for the righteous frustration behind the Steam community's demand for Half-Life 3).  Despite these flaws HL2:E2 is, in my opinion, one of the better Half-Life games out there and succeeds a lot more in creative level design, unique puzzles, evocative story-telling, and just excellent variety in gameplay so you'll never be bored. A wonderful game, but a sad departure from the Half-Life series (hopefully, for now).
